summary: A series of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) clinical encounter notes documenting the medical care and condition of inmate Jeffrey Epstein from his intake in July 2019 until his death on August 10, 2019. The records include routine health assessments, management of chronic conditions, and detailed documentation of a prior injury and the final resuscitation event. This document contains Bureau of Prisons medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering intake health screenings and assessments from July 6-9, 2019, and a transfer summary dated August 10, 2019. It details his medical history, vital signs, diagnoses, and medications while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his incarceration from July 6, 2019, to May 11, 2020. It includes detailed medical charts, medication orders, dental records, psychological notes, and administrative logs from the New York Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYM MCC). This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 29 to August 1, 2019. It includes suicide risk assessments, clinical intervention notes, and a disciplinary competency evaluation following an incident on July 23, 2019, where Epstein was found with a string around his neck. The records consistently note Epstein's denial of suicidal ideation and his future-oriented outlook. This document contains Bureau of Prisons clinical psychology reports detailing Jeffrey Epstein's mental status and conditions while on psychological observation and suicide watch in July 2019, shortly before his death. The reports document his complaints about prison conditions, memory loss regarding neck injuries, and psychological assessments. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychology service reports from July 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's mental health status while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details an incident on July 23, 2019, where Epstein was found with a string around his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch, and his subsequent removal to psychological observation on July 24, 2019, after assessment. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 9-18, 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYM). The records detail psychological observations, suicide risk assessments, and clinical contacts, noting Epstein's complaints about conditions, his psychological stability, and his denial of any suicidal ideation. This document contains multiple Bureau of Prisons psychological assessments for Jeffrey Epstein conducted in July 2019 while he was in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYM). It includes a suicide risk assessment, a general administrative note, and a risk of sexual abusiveness assessment. The assessments conclude Epstein was at low acute suicide risk and low risk of sexual abusiveness in the facility. This document contains Bureau of Prisons medical and psychological intake screening records for Jeffrey Epstein following his arrest in July 2019. It includes a psychological evaluation finding no mental health issues, lab results, and multiple forms where Epstein refused recommended medical examinations, including a chest X-ray, rectal/genital exam, and eye doctor evaluation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The subject of all psychological assessments and clinical contacts. He is evaluated for suicide risk and competency following an incident on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a string around his neck. He denies suicidal ideation and is described as future-oriented.

persons.name: RN Bole
persons.context: Listed as a team member/provider during the emergency resuscitation event on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Beaudouin
persons.context: Physician who completed a clinical encounter note on July 12, 2019, for Epstein's chronic care evaluation.

persons.name: PA-C
persons.context: The healthcare provider who conducted Epstein's initial intake medical encounter on July 6, 2019, documenting his history, observations, and initial orders.

persons.name: MLP
persons.context: A healthcare provider (Mid-Level Provider) who conducted a follow-up medical history and physical examination of Epstein on July 9, 2019.

persons.name: Allen, Tamara
persons.context: An individual from the Office of General Counsel (OGC) who generated a vitals summary report on May 11, 2020.

persons.name: Beaudouin, Robert
persons.context: A doctor who signed off on a medical duty status form for Epstein, specifying housing and equipment restrictions.

persons.name: DeBruce, Juanita
persons.context: A dental assistant who documented a screening encounter at the dental clinic, noting Epstein had several call-outs but was not escorted.

persons.name: PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: The primary provider who conducted multiple psychological assessments, suicide risk evaluations, and clinical interventions with inmate Epstein. The psychologist documented Epstein's status and addressed his complaints.

persons.name: DDS
persons.context: A dentist who performed Epstein's dental health history screening and A&O exam on July 26, 2019, documenting various oral health observations.

persons.name: PsyD
persons.context: The primary psychology provider who conducted multiple suicide risk assessments and clinical contacts with Epstein from July 30 to August 1, 2019. The provider's specific name is not given.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.context: A psychology provider referenced as the author of earlier suicide risk assessments on July 9 and July 23, 2019. The full name is not provided in the text.

persons.name: Proto
persons.context: Referred inmate Epstein for an evaluation of competency to proceed with the disciplinary process regarding incident report number 3282555.

persons.name: PsyD/DAPC
persons.context: A psychology provider who conducted a clinical contact follow-up with Epstein on July 31, 2019, after he was removed from Psychological Observation.

persons.name: SHU Lt.
persons.context: Mentioned as the staff member the psychology provider would talk to about housing Epstein with a different cellmate, and who was informed that Epstein needed an appropriate cellmate.

persons.name: Nurse Columbo
persons.context: Medical staff member who examined Epstein for complaints about numbness in his right arm and neck, as noted in the July 28, 2019 report.

persons.name: Nick
persons.context: Epstein's previous cellmate in SHU whom Epstein asked to speak with to help understand how he received neck injuries, mentioned in the July 26, 2019 report.

persons.name: Samantha DiMisa
persons.context: Ph.D. psychologist who authored the Post Suicide Watch Report on July 24, 2019, assessing Epstein's risk factors and mental status after being removed from suicide watch.

persons.name: PhD/Chief
persons.context: Unnamed chief psychologist who was notified of the suicide watch initiation and authored administrative notes and a SHU review.

persons.name: Operations Lt.
persons.context: Unnamed lieutenant who contacted the on-call psychologist at approximately 2 AM on July 23, 2019, to inform them Epstein was being placed on suicide watch.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: Unnamed captain who was notified about Epstein's statement to staff that his cellmate tried to kill him and stated they were already aware.

persons.name: SHU Lieutenant
persons.context: A staff member in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) whom the chief psychologist informed about Epstein's concerns regarding soap, a spoon, and phone calls.

persons.name: PsyD/PhD
persons.context: A psychologist who conducted the Risk of Sexual Abusiveness assessment for Epstein on July 8, 2019, as required by BOP policy.

persons.name: Dr. [Redacted], Central Office
persons.context: A psychologist from the BOP Central Office consulted by the PhD/Chief Psychologist regarding Epstein's risk factors on July 8, 2019.

persons.name: Epstein's brother
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein as his only family, though he stated he does not have a close relationship with him. This was noted as a static risk factor (lack of family connection) in the suicide assessment.

persons.name: Epstein's attorney
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein during his interview. He expressed confidence in his attorney, described him as competent, and requested to meet with him.

persons.name: Inmate Brown
persons.context: Mentioned once in the psychological evaluation in a sentence about familial suicide history, which appears to be a clerical error where the name 'Brown' was used instead of 'Epstein'.

connections.description: Epstein was evaluated by the MLP for injuries on July 23-24, 2019, during which he made statements about his cellmate.
RN Bole was part of the medical team that responded to Epstein's medical emergency and attempted resuscitation on August 10, 2019.
Dr. Beaudouin was Epstein's physician for a chronic care evaluation on July 12, 2019.
PA-C conducted Epstein's initial medical intake screening and assessment on July 6, 2019.
MD cosigned the medical encounter note completed by PA-C on July 7, 2019.
MD cosigned the medical encounter note completed by MLP on July 11, 2019.
Epstein received psychological assessment and supportive interventions from the chief psychologist during his incarceration.
Dr. Beaudouin authorized medical restrictions and equipment (CPAP) for Epstein.
Epstein underwent dental examinations and history screening conducted by the dentist.
Dental assistant documented attempts to schedule Epstein for a dental screening.
PsyD conducted multiple clinical assessments and suicide risk evaluations of inmate Epstein.
Unit Manager Proto referred Epstein for a competency evaluation related to a disciplinary process.
The Chief Psychologist conducted a clinical session with Epstein and was consulted regarding his care.
Epstein was previously housed with Nick in SHU and requested to speak with him to understand how he received neck injuries.
Nurse Columbo provided medical examination for Epstein's complaints of arm and neck numbness.
Dr. DiMisa conducted psychological assessment of Epstein after his suicide watch and evaluated his risk factors.
Epstein's cellmate in the SHU, who Epstein described as 'agitated' and who allegedly called Epstein a 'pedophile' and was reading a newspaper article about him.
Clinical psychologist assessing Epstein's mental state and suicide risk, providing him with hygiene products and explaining his housing status.
On-call psychologist who conducted the initial suicide risk assessment after the string incident.
Clinical relationship where the psychologist assesses, monitors, and provides interventions for inmate Epstein's mental health and adjustment to incarceration.
Epstein is frequently in attorney conferences and consults with his legal counsel regarding his case and bail hearing.
Epstein informed the psychologist that his brother is his only family, but they do not have a close relationship.
Epstein identified his brother as his only family but stated he does not have a close relationship with him.
Epstein expressed confidence in his attorney, described him as competent, and requested to meet with him while in custody.
The assessing psychologist consulted with a psychologist from the BOP Central Office regarding Epstein's suicide risk factors on July 8, 2019.

events.title: Neck Injury Incident
events.description: Epstein found in his cell with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He had circular erythema (bruising) around his neck. He stated he did not know how it happened and insinuated his cellmate was involved.

events.title: Follow-up on Neck Injury
events.description: Epstein seen for follow-up on neck injury. He again insinuated his cellmate had something to do with the injury but refused to elaborate.

events.title: Right Arm Numbness Episodes
events.description: Epstein reported waking up with no control over his right arm for a few minutes. He was evaluated and a cervical spine X-ray was ordered.

events.title: Cardiac Arrest and Death
events.description: Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at 6:35 AM with circumferential bruising around the neck. CPR was initiated. He was intubated and given epinephrine but remained in asystole. He was transported to a local ER with CPR in progress.

events.title: Intake Health Screening
events.description: Epstein underwent initial health screening and PPD administration upon arrival at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC New York).

events.title: Chronic Care Management
events.description: Multiple encounters documenting management of Epstein's chronic health conditions: hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, prediabetes, hypertension, low back pain, and constipation.

events.title: Epstein Initial Medical Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes his initial medical intake screening at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York following his arrest. A PA-C documents his health history, infectious disease risk factors, and vital signs, noting elevated blood pressure.

events.title: Epstein Follow-up Medical Exam
events.description: Epstein undergoes a more comprehensive medical history and physical examination conducted by a Mid-Level Provider (MLP). The exam includes a review of systems, immunizations, and family history.

events.title: Epstein Medical Transfer Summary Prepared
events.description: A medical transfer summary is generated for Jeffrey Epstein, listing his active health problems, medications, pending appointments, and transfer instructions from MCC New York.

events.title: Epstein's Incarceration Health Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's initial health assessment upon entry into Bureau of Prisons custody, recording vitals, allergies, and initial observations.

events.title: Dental Health Screening
events.description: Epstein undergoes a comprehensive dental health history screening and exam, revealing conditions like gingival recession and a history of treated chlamydia.

events.title: Psychological Follow-up in SHU
events.description: The chief psychologist conducts a follow-up session with Epstein in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Epstein reports feeling okay, denies mental health symptoms or suicidal ideation, complains about prison conditions, and mentions spending time with his attorneys.

events.title: CPAP Machine Issued
events.description: A CPAP machine is issued to Epstein for his diagnosed sleep apnea, with serial number recorded.

events.title: Multiple Health Diagnoses Recorded
events.description: Several chronic health conditions are formally diagnosed and recorded for Epstein, including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, hypertension, low back pain, and neuralgia.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found by staff in his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with a string loosely tied around his neck. He stated he did not remember anything about it.

events.title: Incident Report for Tattooing/Self-Mutilation
events.description: Epstein was charged with code 228 (Tattooing or Self-Mutilation), resulting in incident report number 3282555.

events.title: Competency Evaluation for Disciplinary Process
events.description: Epstein was evaluated by psychology staff and found COMPETENT to proceed with the disciplinary process related to the July 23 incident.

events.title: Status Hearing
events.description: Epstein reported he was going to court for a status hearing on this date.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment After US Marshals Form
events.description: A Suicide Risk Assessment was conducted after R&D staff reported that US Marshals had Epstein sign a form noting he had 'suicidal tendencies' when he was brought back from court the previous day.

events.title: Epstein placed on suicide watch
events.description: Epstein was placed on suicide watch following an incident involving marks on his neck, starting at 01:40.

events.title: Epstein removed from suicide watch
events.description: Epstein was removed from suicide watch after 31 hours and 5 minutes, following psychological assessment by Dr. DiMisa.

events.title: Psychological observation period
events.description: Epstein remained on psychological observation in the hospital area, with daily psychology contacts documenting his mental status, complaints about conditions, and memory issues regarding neck injuries.

events.title: Medical complaint about numbness
events.description: Epstein complained of numbness in his right arm and neck, examined by Nurse Columbo, with follow-up notification on July 28.

events.title: Initial Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: The on-call psychologist (PsyD) conducted a suicide risk assessment. Epstein denied memory of the string incident and suicidal intent. The overall acute suicide risk was assessed as 'Moderate'.

events.title: Removal from Suicide Watch
events.description: Psychologist Samantha DiMisa assessed Epstein and recommended his removal from suicide watch to psychological observation, citing his denial of suicidal intent and future orientation. Overall acute suicide risk was assessed as 'Low'.

events.title: Legal Visit
events.description: Epstein attended a legal visit after being provided a shower, as noted in the psychological report.

events.title: Placed in SHU
events.description: Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) under administrative detention status.

events.title: Epstein returns from court
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein returned from a court proceeding in the evening, leading staff to place him on precautionary psychological observation due to risk factors.

events.title: Suicide risk assessment
events.description: A formal suicide risk assessment was conducted on Epstein at 7:30 AM. He was found to have risk factors (high-profile case, sex charges) but stronger protective factors and no suicidality.

events.title: Release from psychological observation
events.description: Epstein was assessed as psychologically stable with no acute symptoms and was released from the psychological observation area to be housed in the 9S area with a cellmate.

events.title: Psychological follow-up in SHU
events.description: Epstein was seen for a psychological observation follow-up in attorney conference. He raised numerous complaints about incarceration conditions (property, uniform, temperature).

events.title: Clinical contact regarding unmet needs
events.description: Epstein called for the psychologist to complain about not receiving a spoon, soap, and promised phone calls in SHU. Staff later reported he had received two calls.

events.title: Epstein's court proceeding and precautionary observation
events.description: Epstein had a court proceeding. Upon his return to the MCC in the evening, he was placed on precautionary psychological observation due to his risk factors (high-profile case, sex charges). Staff were instructed to notify psychology immediately upon his return.

events.title: Suicide risk assessment interview
events.description: A PhD/Chief Psychologist conducted a clinical interview with Epstein for a suicide risk assessment. Epstein denied any suicidal ideation, was future-oriented, and discussed his upcoming bail hearing.

events.title: Risk of Sexual Abusiveness assessment
events.description: A PsyD/PhD psychologist assessed Epstein's risk for sexual abusiveness per BOP policy (P5324.11). He was judged to be at low risk of abusiveness at the facility but declined sex offender treatment programming.

events.title: Previous incarceration in Palm Beach County
events.description: Epstein reported to the psychologist that he had previously served time in Palm Beach County jail on charges of soliciting prostitution.

events.title: Psychological Intake Screening
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes a psychological intake evaluation at MCC-NY. He denies any history of mental health issues, substance abuse, or being a victim of abuse. He is assessed as Care Level 1 (no significant impairment).

events.title: Blood Collection for Lab Tests
events.description: Blood is drawn from Jeffrey Epstein for comprehensive chemistry, hematology, and serology tests, including an HIV test.

events.title: Refusal of Chest X-Ray
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signs a form refusing a recommended routine chest X-ray for a 66-year-old male with no past medical history.

events.title: Refusal of Eye Exam and Rectal/Genital Exam
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signs two separate forms refusing recommended medical evaluations: an eye doctor evaluation and a rectal and genital examination.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York (150 Park Row, New York, NY 10007)
Mount Sinai Hospital (mentioned as location of past hospitalization for appendicitis in 1990)
New York Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYM MCC)
Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM facility)
Psychological observation area/hospital area at NYM
Palm Beach County jail (mentioned as past incarceration location)
Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM) - The federal facility where Epstein was housed.
Palm Beach County jail - Mentioned by Epstein as where he previously served time.
1900 W. Sunshine Street, Springfield, MO 65807 (U.S. Medical Center for Federal Prisons - lab location)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell on August 10, 2019, at 6:35 AM with 'circumferential bruising around the neck' and was cold to the touch.
On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found with a rope around his neck. He insinuated to medical staff that his cellmate 'had to do with what happened' but refused to give details.
Epstein had reported episodes of right arm numbness and lack of control in late July 2019, for which a cervical spine X-ray was ordered.
Medical records indicate Epstein had multiple chronic health conditions, including sleep apnea for which he did not have access to his CPAP machine for weeks after intake.
The final resuscitation note details extensive life-saving measures, including CPR, intubation, and multiple doses of epinephrine, but Epstein remained in asystole (no heart rhythm).
Jeffrey Epstein's Bureau of Prisons medical intake records show he reported having '10+' female sexual partners in the last 5 years, 'sometimes' used condoms, and had a history of chlamydia in 2015.

Epstein's medical records from July 6 and 9, 2019, document elevated blood pressure readings (up to 164/90) and a subsequent diagnosis of 'essential (primary) hypertension' by the time of his transfer summary on August 10, 2019.

The transfer summary dated August 10, 2019, lists multiple active health problems for Epstein including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, hypertension, constipation, low back pain, neuralgia, prediabetes, and an 'injury, unspecified' with the note 'R/O self inflicted injuries.'
Epstein refused portions of the physical exam on July 9, 2019, specifically the rectal and male genitalia examinations, as noted in the medical record.
The document indicates Epstein traveled to Paris for three weeks 'up until arrest' and was born in the USA, with occupations listed as 'banker' and education as 'high school diploma.'

Jeffrey Epstein had numerous chronic health conditions documented during his incarceration, including sleep apnea, prediabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, low back pain, neuralgia, and constipation.
Epstein was prescribed regular insulin via a sliding scale in July/August 2019, indicating management of blood glucose levels, alongside other medications for pain, constipation, and triglycerides.

A psychological note from August 8, 2019, states Epstein denied any suicidal ideation, intention, or plan, reported spending his days with his attorneys in the conference room, and expressed a desire to move to general population.
Epstein's dental records from July 26, 2019, note a past medical history of treated chlamydia in 2015 and chicken pox in childhood.
The records show Epstein was housed in a single cell on the first floor with a lower bunk restriction and was issued a CPAP machine for sleep apnea.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck; he claimed no memory of the event.
Multiple psychological assessments from July to August 1, 2019, concluded Epstein was not an immediate suicide risk, was future-oriented, and denied suicidal ideation.

Epstein was charged with a disciplinary code for 'Tattooing or Self-Mutilation' (incident report 3282555) related to the July 23 neck incident and was found competent to proceed with the disciplinary process.
Epstein cited sleep problems due to noise in SHU and initially lacking his CPAP machine, and mentioned issues with a cellmate who talked at night.
A US Marshals form dated July 31, 2019, noted Epstein had 'suicidal tendencies,' prompting an additional risk assessment on August 1, which again found low acute risk.
Epstein consistently claimed he could not remember how he received marks and scabs around his neck that led to his suicide watch placement.
Psychological staff noted Epstein's vague accounts and memory lapses regarding the neck injury incident, with one psychologist stating 'the nature of the incident remain unclear.'
Epstein expressed fear about returning to SHU and his previous cellmate, citing safety concerns and poor conditions including noise, smells, and restrictions.
Clinical assessments noted Epstein denied current suicidal ideation, described himself as 'a coward' who doesn't like pain, and was future-oriented about his legal case.
Epstein spent most days in attorney conferences, with correctional staff reporting he was animated, laughing, and joking during these legal visits.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch.

Epstein claimed no memory of the string incident, suggesting he woke up on a stretcher after hearing himself snore. He also told staff his cellmate tried to kill him, a statement he did not repeat to the assessing psychologist.

Epstein's cellmate was described as 'agitated,' had called Epstein a 'pedophile,' and was reading a newspaper article about Epstein, which Epstein found strange and subsequently flushed down the toilet.

On July 24, 2019, a psychological assessment concluded Epstein's acute suicide risk was 'Low' and he was stepped down from suicide watch to psychological observation. Epstein denied suicidal intent, stating he had 'lots to do for [his] legal case' and a 'wonderful life.'
Epstein expressed a desire to be moved from the SHU to general population, claiming his initial unit had 'many MS-13 gang members,' and he felt safer on psychological observation.

Jeffrey Epstein was assessed as having no mental illness, no history of mental health treatment, and no current or past suicidal ideation, despite having risk factors like a high-profile case and sex offense charges.

Epstein made numerous complaints about his incarceration conditions, including lack of property, desire for a single cell, issues with uniforms, constipation medication, and access to phone calls and recreation.

Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation after returning from court on July 8, 2019, due to concerns about potential suicidality risk, but was found to be psychologically stable and future-oriented.
The psychological records note Epstein was consulting frequently with his attorney and was anticipating a bail hearing, expressing belief he would be released.
Epstein's only family mentioned is a brother with whom he does not have a close relationship, but he stated he has a support system of friends and associates in the community.
On July 9, 2019, a BOP psychologist assessed Jeffrey Epstein as having a 'Low' acute suicide risk and 'Absent' chronic suicide risk, concluding a suicide watch was not warranted.

Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation on July 8, 2019, due to risk factors including his high-profile case, sex trafficking charges, pre-trial status, and a court proceeding that day.
A separate BOP assessment on July 8, 2019, judged Epstein to be at 'Low Risk of Abusiveness' for sexual behavior within the facility, though he declined sex offender treatment programming.
Epstein denied any history of mental health treatment, suicidal ideation, or substance abuse during his interviews, and presented as future-oriented, discussing an upcoming bail hearing.
The documents show consultation between facility psychologists and BOP Central Office regarding Epstein's case, indicating institutional awareness of his high-profile status and associated risks.

Jeffrey Epstein underwent a psychological intake on July 8, 2019, where he denied any history of mental health issues, substance abuse, or being a victim of sexual/physical abuse. He was assessed as having no need for regular mental health intervention.

Epstein refused several recommended medical examinations while in custody, including a routine chest X-ray (July 10), a rectal and genital examination (July 9), and an eye doctor evaluation (July 24).

Lab results from blood drawn on July 9, 2019, showed elevated cholesterol (216 mg/dL), high triglycerides (413 mg/dL), low HDL (31 mg/dL), and an elevated Hemoglobin A1c (6.3%), indicating increased risk for diabetes. HIV and RPR (syphilis) tests were negative.
The psychological evaluation contains a probable clerical error, referencing 'Inmate Brown' in a sentence about familial suicide history within a report otherwise entirely about Epstein.
Epstein stated during his intake that he was previously incarcerated for three months for prostitution and was currently charged with sex trafficking.
